title: <italic>bicoid</italic> mRNA localises to the <italic>Drosophila</italic> oocyte anterior by random Dynein-mediated transport and anchoring
abstract: <italic>bicoid</italic> mRNA localises to the <italic>Drosophila</italic> oocyte anterior from stage 9 of oogenesis onwards to provide a local source for Bicoid protein for embryonic patterning. Live imaging at stage 9 reveals that <italic>bicoid</italic> mRNA particles undergo rapid Dynein-dependent movements near the oocyte anterior, but with no directional bias. Furthermore, <italic>bicoid</italic> mRNA localises normally in <italic>shot</italic>, which abolishes the polarised microtubule organisation. FRAP and photo-conversion experiments demonstrate that the RNA is stably anchored at the anterior, independently of microtubules. Thus, <italic>bicoid</italic> mRNA is localised by random active transport and anterior anchoring. Super-resolution imaging reveals that <italic>bicoid</italic> mRNA forms 110–120 nm particles with variable RNA content, but constant size. These particles appear to be well-defined structures that package the RNA for transport and anchoring.
